title: Marks and Spencer reports 7% fall in formal wear sales as top City firms relax dress code
text:
It was once said that a well-tied tie is the first serious step in life – but formal tailoring seems to be going out of fashion.

In a presentation to financial analysts this week, Marks and Spencer said it had seen a market-wide 7 per cent fall in formalwear sales.

Sales of ties have dropped by nearly 6 per cent year on year, while blazers and jackets have fallen by 10 per cent.

As a result, the store – which sells one in seven suits in the UK – is reducing the number of formalwear ranges. The firm will also shrink the amount of space it uses to sell suits in store.

Top City banks, such as Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan, have relaxed their dress code in recent years in order to attract staff tempted by tech firms. At Facebook and Apple, casual attire is encouraged in the office.

More than £100million has been wiped off annual suit sales since 2015. About £393million was spent on suits by UK men in the year to the end of August – with an average purchase price of £102.

‘There are things it’s still deemed you need to wear a suit for, but those events are becoming fewer and farther between,’ Glen Tooke, from market analysts Kantar told The Guardian.
